awd_titl_txt: TRANSFORM-PGR: Mining the compact Utricularia genome as source of novel regulatory elements for crop biotechnology
awd_abstract_narration:
The goal of this project is to advance plant genetic engineering technology and enable next-generation research and plant-improvement to help meet the upcoming challenges in agriculture.  The need for increased but sustainable food production needs to be addressed through many approaches.  Bioengineering can help address human food security through crop improvement.  These improved crops will range from varieties highly adapted to diverse climates to crops with improved nutrition, that are better able to resist pests, use less water and fertilizer, or make the raw materials for bioplastics and other biodegradable materials.  To make these plants a reality, it is first necessary to develop the ability to bioengineer multiple traits into plants.  Current technology can place many genes close together and insert them into a crop; however, placing these genes close to each other causes them to interfere with each other. Hence, plants typically put a lot of space between their genes, but there is at least one plant known, the bladderwort, that has solved the problem of gene spacing its genome has many genes that are close together, but do not interfere with one another.  The bladderwort also contains shortened versions of other DNA sequences that control when and where genes are expressed.  This project uses bioinformatics to identify the bladderwort DNA sequences that allow for close spacing of genes, and to isolate the shorter versions of DNA control sequences.  The function of each sequence will be validated empirically, and then made publicly available. The research team will also use the bladderwort sequences to find similar control sequences in other plants, including important crop species.

Currently, the lack of appropriate DNA regulatory elements can make it difficult to get coordinated expression of multiple genes cloned into one vector.  A few DNA insulators have been identified in plants that prevent interference from neighboring genes, but these insulators are so large their use makes vectors impossibly large.  The compact genome (just 82 Mb) of Utricularia gibba (bladderwort) has solved many of these expression issues as it evolved.  Expression patterns makes it clear this species has compact promoters, terminators, and insulators, as well as bidirectional promoters.  Identification, cloning and validation of these elements and their function will provide a set of tools that will enable the routine use of multiple gene engineering.  The DNA elements identified in this project will be made publicly available via AddGene, and thus contribute to a new generation of genetic engineering vectors. The researchers will also use the bladderwort sequences to identify similar conserved regulatory elements across angiosperms.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

inst.inst_name: University of Georgia Research Foundation Inc
inst.org_lgl_bus_name: UNIVERSITY OF GEORGIA RESEARCH FOUNDATION, INC.

por.por_cntn:
Plant genetic engineering involves putting genes into plants, either for research (to understand what the genes do) or for production (to transfer or create new traits we find useful, like resistance to drought or a disease). Scientists often want to move several genes at once because they function together or because it is simply faster. However, this means the genes have to be close together on a single piece of DNA. Once in the plant, these genes can start to interfere with each other, so that the genetic controls for one gene start bleeding over into neighboring genes, disrupting the tight control we usually want to ensure genes are expressed when and where they are actually needed.

To prevent this disregulation, resaerchers can use "insulator-like elements" that help isolate a gene from nearby genes. Unfortanately, very few of these are known in plants, and the ones we do have tend to be relatively big, which makes them harder to use. We studied the genome of a small, aquatic plant called humped bladderwort (Utricularia gibba). This plant is a common weed in ponds and lakes throughout North America, where it uses microscopic "bladders" to trap and digest food, similar to a venus flytrap. FOr our project, though, it is most remarkable for its tiny genome, one of the smallest known among plants. This means that its genes are naturally very close togehter, and it may already have natural ways of keeping them from interfering with each other.

Intellectual merit.  We scanned the bladderwort genome for stretches of DNA between genes that could be new insulator-like elements. We used gene expression in bladderwort itself to find high-quality candidates, and we looked for similar regions in many other flowering plants to narrow down our list to the ones that looked most robust. After testing 20 of these across two different experiment sets, we found three new insulator-like elements that show good properties in our tests. A second search yielded two more elements. 

Broader impacts.   A total of five insulator-like elements were identified.  These five elements are as good or better as existing ones and usually much shorter, which makes them extremely valuable for genetic engineering.   All the sequences we found have been made completely public, so anyone can use them. We expect that these elements will be very useful for making multi-gene constructs for genetic engineering of crop plants, and that they will help make plant genetic engineering both more powerful and more precise.

 


Last Modified: 07/11/2024
Modified by: Wayne Parrott

Images (1 of )

    Lynsey Kovar
    Copyrighted
    Jason G Wallace
    Humped bladderwort (Utricularia gibba)
  • Insulator activity of sequences previously reported in the literature compared to the activity of the Gibba-derived sequences (blue). The largest & least effective sequences are in the upper right, while the smallest, most effective sequences are in the lower left.
    Eudald Illa-Berenguer
    Copyrighted
    Wayne Parrott
    Relative size and efficiency of insulator-like sequences
